an5.41:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an5.41:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an5.41:1.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an5.41:1.2.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an5.41:1.3.eng: “Householder, there are these five reasons to get rich.

an5.41:1.5.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati;
an5.41:1.5.eng: Firstly, with his legitimate wealth—earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow—a noble disciple makes himself happy and pleased, keeping himself properly happy.

an5.41:1.6.pli: mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati;
an5.41:1.6.eng: He makes his mother and father happy …

an5.41:1.7.pli: puttadāradāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an5.41:1.7.eng: He makes his children, partners, bondservants, workers, and staff happy …

an5.41:1.8.eng: This is the first reason to get rich.

an5.41:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an5.41:2.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes his friends and colleagues happy …

an5.41:2.2.eng: This is the second reason to get rich.

an5.41:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi yā tā honti āpadā—
an5.41:3.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he protects himself against losses from such things as fire, water, kings, bandits, or unloved heirs.

an5.41:3.2.pli: aggito vā udakato vā rājato vā corato vā appiyato vā dāyādato—

an5.41:3.3.pli: tathārūpāsu āpadāsu bhogehi pariyodhāya vattati, sotthiṃ attānaṃ karoti.

an5.41:3.4.eng: This is the third reason to get rich.

an5.41:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi pañcabaliṃ kattā hoti.
an5.41:4.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes five spirit-offerings:

an5.41:4.2.eng: to relatives, guests, ancestors, king, and deities.

an5.41:4.3.eng: This is the fourth reason to get rich.

an5.41:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā madappamādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṃ damenti ekamattānaṃ samenti ekamattānaṃ parinibbāpenti, tathārūpesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
an5.41:5.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he establishes an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins—those who refrain from intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves—that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

an5.41:5.2.eng: This is the fifth reason to get rich.

an5.41:5.3.pli: Ime kho, gahapati, pañca bhogānaṃ ādiyā.
an5.41:5.3.eng: These are the five reasons to get rich.

an5.41:6.1.pli: Tassa ce, gahapati, ariyasāvakassa ime pañca bhogānaṃ ādiye ādiyato bhogā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, tassa evaṃ hoti:
an5.41:6.1.eng: Now if the riches a noble disciple gets for these five reasons run out, he thinks:

an5.41:6.2.pli: ‘ye vata bhogānaṃ ādiyā te cāhaṃ ādiyāmi bhogā ca me parikkhayaṃ gacchantī’ti.
an5.41:6.2.eng: ‘So, the riches I have obtained for these reasons are running out.’

an5.41:6.3.eng: And so he has no regrets.

an5.41:6.4.pli: Tassa ce, gahapati, ariyasāvakassa ime pañca bhogānaṃ ādiye ādiyato bhogā abhivaḍḍhanti, tassa evaṃ hoti:
an5.41:6.4.eng: But if the riches a noble disciple gets for these five reasons increase, he thinks:

an5.41:6.5.pli: ‘ye vata bhogānaṃ ādiyā te cāhaṃ ādiyāmi bhogā ca me abhivaḍḍhantī’ti.
an5.41:6.5.eng: ‘So, the riches I have obtained for these reasons are increasing.’

an5.41:6.6.eng: And so he has no regrets in both cases.

an5.41:7.1.eng: ‘I’ve enjoyed my wealth, <j>supporting those who depend on me;

an5.41:7.5.eng: I have looked after the ethical and

an5.41:8.4.eng: I don’t regret what I’ve done.’

an5.41:9.1.eng: A mortal man who recollects this

an5.41:9.2.eng: stands firm in the teaching of the noble ones.

an5.41:9.3.eng: They’re praised in this life by the astute,

an5.41:9.4.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

an5.42:1.1.pli: “Sappuriso, bhikkhave, kule jāyamāno bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti;
an5.42:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a true person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.

an5.42:1.2.eng: For the benefit, welfare, and happiness of mother and father;

an5.42:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāmegho sabbasassāni sampādento bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti;
an5.42:2.1.eng: It’s like a great rain cloud, which nourishes all the crops for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.

an5.42:2.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso kule jāyamāno bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti;
an5.42:2.2.eng: In the same way, a true person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people. …

an5.42:3.1.eng: The gods protect one who is guarded by principle,

an5.42:3.2.eng: who uses their wealth for the welfare of the many.

an5.42:3.3.eng: One who is learned, <j>with precepts and observances intact,

an5.42:3.4.eng: and steady in principle, doesn’t lose their reputation.

an5.42:4.1.eng: Firm in principle, accomplished in ethical conduct,

an5.42:4.3.eng: like a pendant of Black Plum River gold,

an5.42:4.4.eng: who is worthy to criticize them?

an5.42:4.6.eng: and by the Divinity, too, they’re praised.”

an5.43:1.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an5.43:1.1.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an5.43:2.1.pli: “Pañcime, gahapati, dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dullabhā lokasmiṃ.
an5.43:2.1.eng: “Householder, these five things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable are hard to get in the world.

an5.43:2.3.pli: Āyu, gahapati, iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ;

an5.43:2.4.pli: vaṇṇo iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ;

an5.43:2.5.pli: sukhaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpaṃ dullabhaṃ lokasmiṃ;

an5.43:2.6.pli: yaso iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ;

an5.43:2.7.pli: saggā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dullabhā lokasmiṃ.

an5.43:2.8.pli: Ime kho, gahapati, pañca dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dullabhā lokasmiṃ.
an5.43:2.8.eng: These are the five things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.

an5.43:3.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, gahapati, pañcannaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ dullabhānaṃ lokasmiṃ na āyācanahetu vā patthanāhetu vā paṭilābhaṃ vadāmi.
an5.43:3.1.eng: And I say that these five things are not got by supplication or wishing for them.

an5.43:3.2.pli: Imesaṃ kho, gahapati, pañcannaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ dullabhānaṃ lokasmiṃ āyācanahetu vā patthanāhetu vā paṭilābho abhavissa, ko idha kena hāyetha?
an5.43:3.2.eng: If they were, who would lack them?

an5.43:4.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, arahati ariyasāvako āyukāmo āyuṃ āyācituṃ vā abhinandituṃ vā āyussa vāpi hetu.
an5.43:4.1.eng: A noble disciple who wants to live long ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.

an5.43:4.2.pli: Āyukāmena, gahapati, ariyasāvakena āyusaṃvattanikā paṭipadā paṭipajjitabbā.
an5.43:4.2.eng: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to long life.

an5.43:4.3.pli: Āyusaṃvattanikā hissa paṭipadā paṭipannā āyupaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an5.43:4.3.eng: For by practicing that way they gain long life

an5.43:4.4.pli: So lābhī hoti āyussa dibbassa vā mānusassa vā.
an5.43:4.4.eng: as a god or a human being.

an5.43:5.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, arahati ariyasāvako vaṇṇakāmo vaṇṇaṃ āyācituṃ vā abhinandituṃ vā vaṇṇassa vāpi hetu.
an5.43:5.1.eng: A noble disciple who wants to be beautiful ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.

an5.43:5.2.pli: Vaṇṇakāmena, gahapati, ariyasāvakena vaṇṇasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā paṭipajjitabbā.
an5.43:5.2.eng: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to beauty.

an5.43:5.3.pli: Vaṇṇasaṃvattanikā hissa paṭipadā paṭipannā vaṇṇapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an5.43:5.3.eng: For by practicing that way they gain beauty

an5.43:5.4.pli: So lābhī hoti vaṇṇassa dibbassa vā mānusassa vā.
an5.43:5.4.eng: as a god or a human being.

an5.43:6.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, arahati ariyasāvako sukhakāmo sukhaṃ āyācituṃ vā abhinandituṃ vā sukhassa vāpi hetu.
an5.43:6.1.eng: A noble disciple who wants to be happy ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.

an5.43:6.2.pli: Sukhakāmena, gahapati, ariyasāvakena sukhasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā paṭipajjitabbā.
an5.43:6.2.eng: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to happiness.

an5.43:6.3.pli: Sukhasaṃvattanikā hissa paṭipadā paṭipannā sukhapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an5.43:6.3.eng: For by practicing that way they gain happiness

an5.43:6.4.pli: So lābhī hoti sukhassa dibbassa vā mānusassa vā.
an5.43:6.4.eng: as a god or a human being.

an5.43:7.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, arahati ariyasāvako yasakāmo yasaṃ āyācituṃ vā abhinandituṃ vā yasassa vāpi hetu.
an5.43:7.1.eng: A noble disciple who wants to be famous ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.

an5.43:7.2.pli: Yasakāmena, gahapati, ariyasāvakena yasasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā paṭipajjitabbā.
an5.43:7.2.eng: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to fame.

an5.43:7.3.pli: Yasasaṃvattanikā hissa paṭipadā paṭipannā yasapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an5.43:7.3.eng: For by practicing that way they gain fame

an5.43:7.4.pli: So lābhī hoti yasassa dibbassa vā mānusassa vā.
an5.43:7.4.eng: as a god or a human being.

an5.43:8.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, arahati ariyasāvako saggakāmo saggaṃ āyācituṃ vā abhinandituṃ vā saggānaṃ vāpi hetu.
an5.43:8.1.eng: A noble disciple who wants to go to heaven ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.

an5.43:8.2.pli: Saggakāmena, gahapati, ariyasāvakena saggasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā paṭipajjitabbā.
an5.43:8.2.eng: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to heaven.

an5.43:8.3.pli: Saggasaṃvattanikā hissa paṭipadā paṭipannā saggapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an5.43:8.3.eng: For by practicing that way they gain heaven,

an5.43:8.4.eng: they are one who gains the heavens.

an5.43:9.1.eng: For one who desires lofty delights

an5.43:9.3.eng: long life, beauty, fame and reputation,

an5.43:11.3.eng: An attentive one, comprehending the meaning,

an5.44:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an5.44:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an5.44:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena uggassa gahapatino vesālikassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an5.44:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the householder Ugga of Vesālī, where he sat on the seat spread out.

an5.44:1.3.pli: Atha kho uggo gahapati vesāliko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggo gahapati vesāliko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.44:1.3.eng: Then Ugga went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an5.44:2.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
an5.44:2.1.eng: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an5.44:2.2.eng: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’

an5.44:2.3.eng: My sal flower porridge is agreeable:

an5.44:2.4.pli: taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:2.4.eng: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:2.5.eng: So the Buddha accepted it out of sympathy.

an5.44:3.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
an5.44:3.1.eng: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an5.44:3.2.eng: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’

an5.44:3.3.eng: My pork with jujube is agreeable:

an5.44:3.4.pli: taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:3.4.eng: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:3.5.eng: So the Buddha accepted it out of sympathy.

an5.44:4.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an5.44:4.3.eng: “… My fried vegetable stalks are agreeable:

an5.44:4.4.pli: taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:4.4.eng: may the Buddha please accept them from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:4.5.eng: So the Buddha accepted them out of sympathy.

an5.44:5.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an5.44:5.3.pli: Manāpo me, bhante, sālīnaṃ odano vicitakāḷako anekasūpo anekabyañjano;
an5.44:5.3.eng: “… My boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces is agreeable:

an5.44:5.4.pli: taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:5.4.eng: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:5.5.eng: So the Buddha accepted it out of sympathy.

an5.44:6.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an5.44:6.3.eng: “… My cloths imported from Kāsi are agreeable:

an5.44:6.4.pli: tāni me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:6.4.eng: may the Buddha please accept them from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:6.5.eng: So the Buddha accepted them out of sympathy.

an5.44:7.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an5.44:7.3.pli: Manāpo me, bhante, pallaṅko gonakatthato paṭalikatthato kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇo sauttaracchado ubhatolohitakūpadhāno.
an5.44:7.3.eng: “… My couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends is agreeable.

an5.44:7.5.eng: this is not proper for the Buddha.

an5.44:7.6.pli: Idaṃ me, bhante, candanaphalakaṃ agghati adhikasatasahassaṃ;
an5.44:7.6.eng: However, this plank of sandalwood is worth over a thousand dollars.

an5.44:7.7.pli: taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an5.44:7.7.eng: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of sympathy.”

an5.44:7.8.eng: So the Buddha accepted it out of sympathy.

an5.44:7.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uggaṃ gahapatiṃ vesālikaṃ iminā anumodanīyena anumodi:
an5.44:7.9.eng: And then the Buddha rejoiced with Ugga with these verses of appreciation:

an5.44:8.1.eng: “The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable,

an5.44:8.3.eng: food and drink, and various requisites

an5.44:9.1.eng: Knowing the perfected ones to be like a field

an5.44:9.2.eng: for what’s given, offered and not held back,

an5.44:9.3.eng: a true person gives what’s hard to give:

an5.44:9.4.eng: the giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.”

an5.44:10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uggaṃ gahapatiṃ vesālikaṃ iminā anumodanīyena anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
an5.44:10.1.eng: And then the Buddha, having rejoiced with Ugga with these verses of appreciation, got up from his seat and left.

an5.44:11.1.pli: Atha kho uggo gahapati vesāliko aparena samayena kālamakāsi.
an5.44:11.1.eng: Then after some time Ugga passed away,

an5.44:11.2.pli: Kālaṅkato ca uggo gahapati vesāliko aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapajji.
an5.44:11.2.eng: and was reborn in a host of mind-made gods.

an5.44:11.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an5.44:11.3.eng: At that time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an5.44:11.4.pli: Atha kho uggo devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho uggaṃ devaputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an5.44:11.4.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Ugga, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an5.44:11.5.eng: “Ugga, I trust it is all you wished?”

an5.44:11.6.eng: “Sir, it is indeed just as I wished.”

an5.44:11.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uggaṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
an5.44:11.7.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Ugga in verse:

an5.44:12.1.eng: “The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable,

an5.44:12.2.eng: the giver of the foremost gets the foremost,

an5.44:12.3.eng: the giver of the excellent gets the excellent,

an5.44:12.4.eng: the giver of the best gets the best.

an5.44:13.1.eng: A person who gives the foremost,

an5.45:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā sovaggikā sukhavipākā saggasaṃvattanikā iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti.
an5.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.

an5.45:2.2.pli: Yassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cīvaraṃ paribhuñjamāno appamāṇaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, appamāṇo tassa puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an5.45:2.2.eng: When a mendicant enters and remains in a limitless immersion of heart while using a robe …

an5.45:3.1.pli: Yassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjamāno …pe… yassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vihāraṃ paribhuñjamāno …pe… yassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mañcapīṭhaṃ paribhuñjamāno …pe….

an5.45:4.1.pli: Yassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ paribhuñjamāno appamāṇaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, appamāṇo tassa puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an5.45:4.1.eng: medicines and supplies for the sick, the overflowing of merit for the donor is limitless …

an5.45:4.2.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā sovaggikā sukhavipākā saggasaṃvattanikā iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti.
an5.45:4.2.eng: These are the five kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness, and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness, and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.

an5.45:5.1.pli: Imehi ca pana, bhikkhave, pañcahi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ:
an5.45:5.1.eng: When a noble disciple has these five kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to grasp how much merit they have by saying that

an5.45:5.2.pli: ‘ettako puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattatī’ti.
an5.45:5.2.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit … that leads to happiness.

an5.45:5.3.pli: Atha kho asaṅkheyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.45:5.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.

an5.45:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde na sukaraṃ udakassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ:
an5.45:6.1.eng: It’s like trying to grasp how much water is in the ocean. It’s not easy to say:

an5.45:6.2.pli: ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakānīti vā ettakāni udakāḷhakasatānīti vā ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassānīti vā ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassānīti vā;
an5.45:6.2.eng: ‘This is how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.’

an5.45:6.3.pli: atha kho asaṅkheyyo appameyyo mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati’.
an5.45:6.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.

an5.45:6.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, imehi pañcahi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ:
an5.45:6.4.eng: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these five kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to grasp how much merit they have:

an5.45:6.5.pli: ‘ettako puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattatī’ti.
an5.45:6.5.eng: ‘This is how much this overflowing merit … leads to happiness.’

an5.45:6.6.pli: Atha kho asaṅkheyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti.
an5.45:6.6.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.

an5.45:7.1.eng: Hosts of people use the rivers,

an5.45:7.2.eng: and though the rivers are many,

an5.45:7.3.eng: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,

an5.45:7.4.eng: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.

an5.45:8.1.eng: So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;

an5.45:8.2.eng: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—

an5.45:8.3.eng: the streams of merit reach that astute person,

an5.45:8.4.eng: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”

an5.46:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an5.47:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of wealth.

an5.47:1.3.eng: The wealth of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an5.47:2.1.eng: And what is the wealth of faith?

an5.47:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an5.47:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

an5.47:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an5.47:2.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an5.47:2.4.eng: This is called the wealth of faith.

an5.47:3.1.eng: And what is the wealth of ethics?

an5.47:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
an5.47:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an5.47:3.3.eng: This is called the wealth of ethics.

an5.47:4.1.eng: And what is the wealth of learning?

an5.47:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdho.
an5.47:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.47:4.3.eng: This is called the wealth of learning.

an5.47:5.1.eng: And what is the wealth of generosity?

an5.47:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vosaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an5.47:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an5.47:5.3.eng: This is called the wealth of generosity.

an5.47:6.1.eng: And what is the wealth of wisdom?

an5.47:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an5.47:6.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.47:6.3.eng: This is called the wealth of wisdom.

an5.47:6.4.eng: These are the five kinds of wealth.

an5.47:7.1.eng: Whoever has faith in the Realized One,

an5.47:7.4.eng: praised and loved by the noble ones;

an5.47:8.1.eng: who has confidence in the Saṅgha,

an5.47:8.4.eng: their life is not in vain.

an5.47:9.1.eng: So let the wise devote themselves

an5.47:9.3.eng: confidence, and insight into the teaching,

an5.47:9.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”
